solution_line_template: If the total cost of an orange and a pear is ${total_cost_orange_pear}, and a pear costs ${cost_pear}, an orange costs ${total_cost_orange_pear}-${cost_pear} = $<<{total_cost_orange_pear}-{cost_pear}={cost_orange}>>{cost_orange}
Since the difference between the price of an orange and a pear is the price of a banana, a banana is sold at ${cost_pear}-${cost_orange} = $<<{cost_pear}-{cost_orange}={cost_banana}>>{cost_banana}
When you twice as many oranges as bananas, you buy {multiplier_oranges}*{num_bananas_to_buy} = <<{multiplier_oranges}*{num_bananas_to_buy}={num_oranges_to_buy}>>{num_oranges_to_buy} oranges.
The total cost of buying {num_oranges_to_buy} oranges is {num_oranges_to_buy}*{cost_orange} = $<<{num_oranges_to_buy}*{cost_orange}={cost_oranges}>>{cost_oranges}
The total price of buying 200 bananas and twice as many oranges as bananas is ${cost_200_bananas}+${cost_oranges} = ${total_price}
